member.name: T:Atom.Math.Complex
member.summary: Defines a complex number (x,yi). C = x + yi, where i^2=(-1).
member.remarks: Complexs numbers are an extension of the real numbers to allow the representation of square roots of negative numbers. Any real number is a complex number of type (x,0). Any complex number of type (0,-y) is a square root of a negative real number.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.CurveTangent
member.summary: Specifies different tangent types to be calculated for CurveKey points in a Curve.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveTangent.Flat
member.summary: A Flat tangent always has a value equal to zero.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveTangent.Linear
member.summary: A Linear tangent at a CurveKey is equal to the difference between its CurveKey.Value and the Value of the preceding or succeeding CurveKey.
member.example: For example, in Curve MyCurve, where i is greater than zero and (i + 1) is less than the total number of CurveKeys in MyCurve, the linear CurveKey.TangentIn of MyCurve.Keys[i] is equal to: ( MyCurve.Keys[i].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Value )Similarly, the linear CurveKey.TangentOut is equal to: ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i].Value.)

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveTangent.Smooth
member.summary: A Smooth tangent smooths the inflection between a CurveKey.TangentIn and CurveKey.TangentOut by taking into account the values of both neighbors of the CurveKey.

example.para: The smooth CurveKey.TangentIn of MyCurve.Keys[i] is equal to: ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Value ) * ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Position ) / ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i-1].Position ) ) )

Similarly, the smooth CurveKey.TangentOut is equal to: ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Value ) * ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i].Position ) / ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Position ) ) )

member.name: T:Atom.Math.CurveLoopType
member.summary: Defines how the value of a Curve will be determined for positions before the first point on the Curve or after the last point on the Curve.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveLoopType.Constant
member.summary: The Curve will evaluate to its first key for positions before the first point in the Curve and to the last key for positions after the last point.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveLoopType.Cycle
member.summary: Positions specified past the ends of the curve will wrap around to the opposite side of the Curve.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveLoopType.CycleOffset
member.summary: Positions specified past the ends of the curve will wrap around to the opposite side of the Curve. The value will be offset by the difference between the values of the first and last CurveKey multiplied by the number of times the position wraps around. If the position is before the first point in the Curve, the difference will be subtracted from its value; otherwise, the difference will be added.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveLoopType.Oscillate
member.summary: Linear interpolation will be performed to determine the value.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveLoopType.Linear
member.summary: Positions specified past the ends of the Curve act as an offset from the same side of the Curve toward the opposite side.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.CurveContinuity
member.summary: Defines the continuity of CurveKeys on a Curve.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveContinuity.Smooth
member.summary: Interpolation can be used between this CurveKey and the next.

member.name: F:Atom.Math.CurveContinuity.Step
member.summary: Interpolation cannot be used between this CurveKey and the next. Specifying a position between the two points returns this point.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.DelaunyTriangulation
member.summary: Performs the Delauney triangulation on a set of vertices. Only returns expected results with non-complex, convex polygons.
member.remarks: Based on Paul Bourke's "An Algorithm for Interpolating Irregularly-Spaced Data with Applications in Terrain Modelling" (http://astronomy.swin.edu.au/~pbourke/modelling/triangulate/).

member.name: M:Atom.Math.DelaunyTriangulation.Triangulate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Atom.Math.Vector2})
member.summary: Performs Delauney triangulation on a set of points.

remarks.para:
The triangulation algorithm may be described in pseudo-code as follows:
subroutine Triangulate input : vertex list output : triangle list initialize the triangle list determine the supertriangle add supertriangle vertices to the end of the vertex list add the supertriangle to the triangle list for each sample point in the vertex list initialize the edge buffer for each triangle currently in the triangle list calculate the triangle circumcircle center and radius if the point lies in the triangle circumcircle then add the three triangle edges to the edge buffer remove the triangle from the triangle list endif endfor delete all doubly specified edges from the edge buffer this leaves the edges of the enclosing polygon only add to the triangle list all triangles formed between the point and the edges of the enclosing polygon endfor remove any triangles from the triangle list that use the supertriangle vertices remove the supertriangle vertices from the vertex list end

member.param: The list of vertices to triangulate.
member.exception: If is null.
If contains less than 3 vertices.
member.returns: Triangles referencing vertex indices arranged in clockwise order.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.RollingAverage
member.summary: Helpts in averaging out a stream of floating-point values.
member.remarks:
Microsoft XNA Community Game Platform Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
To compensate for network latency, we need to know exactly how late each packet is. Trouble is, there is no guarantee that the clock will be set the same on every machine! The sender can include packet data indicating what time their clock showed when they sent the packet, but this is meaningless unless our local clock is in sync with theirs. To compensate for any clock skew, we maintain a rolling average of the send times from the last 100 incoming packets. If this average is, say, 50 milliseconds, but one specific packet arrives with a time difference of 70 milliseconds, we can deduce this particular packet was delivered 20 milliseconds later than usual.

member.summary: Gets the current value of the rolling average.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the RollingAverage class.

member.summary: Adds a new value to the rolling average, automatically replacing the oldest existing entry.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.PositionalSpline3
member.summary: A Catmull-Rom spline that can be used for interpolating translation movements in 3 dimensional space.

remarks.para: A Catmull-Rom spline is a derivitive of the Hermite spline. The difference is that the Hermite spline allows you to specifiy 2 endpoints and 2 tangents, then the spline is generated. A Catmull-Rom spline allows you to just supply 1-n number of points and the tangents will be automatically calculated.
Derivation of the hermite polynomial can be found here: Hermite splines.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.RotationalSpline3
member.summary: A class used to interpolate orientations (rotations) along a spline using derivatives of quaternions.

remarks.para: Like the class, this class is about interpolating values smoothly over a spline. Whilst deals with positions (the normal sense we think about splines), this class interpolates orientations. The theory is identical, except we're now in 4-dimensional space instead of 3.

In positional splines, we use the points and tangents on those points to generate control points for the spline. In this case, we use quaternions and derivatives of the quaternions (i.e. the rate and direction of change at each point). This is the same as PositionalSpline since a tangent is a derivative of a position. We effectively generate an extra quaternion in between each actual quaternion which when take with the original quaternion forms the 'tangent' of that quaternion.

member.summary: Interpolates a single segment of the spline given a parametric value.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition
member.summary: Implements Cholesky Decomposition of a rectangular . This class can't be inherited.
member.remarks: Adapted from the NGenerics framework, the JAMA package : http://math.nist.gov/javanumerics/jama/ and from Numerical recipes.

member.name: P:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition.LeftFactor
member.summary: Gets the lower triangular factor U^T, with A=U^T x U.
member.value: The triangular factor 'L'.

member.name: P:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition.RightFactor
member.summary: Gets the upper triangular factor U, with A=U^T x U.
member.value: The transpose of the triangular factor 'L'.

member.name: P:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition.TriangularFactorL
member.summary: Gets the triangular factor 'L'.
member.value: The triangular factor 'L'.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition.#ctor(Atom.Math.Matrix)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A square, symmetric input matrix.
member.exception: If is null.
If the specified is a not symmetric.
If the specified is a not square.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition.Decompose(Atom.Math.Matrix)
member.summary: Given a positive-definite symmetric matrix A[0..n][0..n], this routine constructs its Cholesky decomposition, A = L*(L^T) .
member.remarks: The operations count is (N^3)/6 executions of the inner loop (consisting of one multiply and one subtract), with also N square roots. This is about a factor 2 better than LU decomposition of A (where its symmetry would be ignored).
member.param: The square symmetric definite-defined input matrix A.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition.QuickDecompose(Atom.Math.Matrix)
member.summary: Given a positive-definite symmetric matrix A[0..n][0..n], this routine constructs its Cholesky decomposition, A = L*(L^T) .
member.remarks: The operations count is (N^3)/6 executions of the inner loop (consisting of one multiply and one subtract), with also N square roots. This is about a factor 2 better than LU decomposition of A (where its symmetry would be ignored).
member.param: The square symmetric definite-defined input matrix A.
member.exception: If is null.
If is not symmetric.
If is not square.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.CholeskyDecomposition.QuickSolveLinearEquation(Atom.Math.Matrix,System.Single[])
member.summary: Solves the set of n linear equations A * x = b .
member.param: A positive-definite symmetric input matrix [0..n][0..n].
The right-hand side input vector [0..n].
member.returns: The solution vector is returned as [0..n].

member.summary: Solves the equation A*X = B.
member.param: The input matrix B, with as many rows as A and any number of columns.
member.returns: The matrix X; so that L*L'*X = B.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.LUDecomposition
member.summary: Implements LU decomposition of rectangular Matrices. This is a sealed class.
member.remarks: Given a m-by-n Matrix A (with m >= n), the LU decomposition is a m-by-n unit lower triangular Matrix L, a n-by-n upper triangular Matrix U and a permutation point PIV of length m so that A(piv)=L*U. If m < n, then L is m-bx-m and U m-by-n.
Adapted from the JAMA package : http://math.nist.gov/javanumerics/jama/

member.name: P:Atom.Math.LUDecomposition.LeftFactor
member.summary: Gets the lower triangular factor L, with A=LU.
member.value: The lower triangular factor.

member.name: P:Atom.Math.LUDecomposition.RightFactor
member.summary: Gets the upper triangular factor U, with A=LU.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.QRDecomposition
member.summary: In linear algebra, the QR decomposition (also called the QR factorization) of a is a decomposition of the matrix into an orthogonal and a triangular matrix. The QR decomposition is often used to solve the linear least squares problem. The QR decomposition is also the basis for a particular eigenvalue algorithm, the QR algorithm.
member.remarks: Given a Row-by-Columns matrix A (with Rows >= Columns), the result of the QR decomposition is a Rows-by-Columns orthogonal matrix Q and a Columns-by-Columns upper triangular matrix R so that A = Q*R.
Adapted from the JAMA package : http://math.nist.gov/javanumerics/jama/

member.name: P:Atom.Math.QRDecomposition.LeftFactor
member.summary: Gets the (economy-sized) orthogonal factor Q, with A=QR.
member.value: The orthogonal factor.

member.name: P:Atom.Math.QRDecomposition.RightFactor
member.summary: Gets the the upper triangular factor R, with A=QR.
member.value: The upper triangular factor.

member.summary: Gets the row-count of the decomposed matrix.

member.summary: Gets the column-count of the decomposed matrix.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix is full rank.
member.value: Returns if R, and hence A, has full rank; otherwise .

member.summary: Gets the Householder vectors.
member.value: Lower trapezoidal matrix whose columns define the reflections.

member.summary: Gets the the upper triangular factor of the decomposition.
member.value: A new Matrix that contains the upper triangular factor.

member.summary: Gets the (economy-sized) orthogonal factor.
member.value: A new Matrix that contains the (economy-sized) orthogonal factor.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.SingularValueDecomposition
member.summary: Implements Singular Value decomposition of rectangular Matrices. This is a sealed class.

remarks.para: For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the singular value decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal matrix U, an n-by-n diagonal matrix S, and an n-by-n orthogonal matrix V so that A = U*S*V'.
The singular values, sigma[k] = S[k, k], are ordered so that sigma[0] >= sigma[1] >= ... >= sigma[n-1].
The singular value decompostion always exists, so the constructor will never fail. The matrix condition number and the effective numerical rank can be computed from this decomposition.

member.name: P:Atom.Math.SingularValueDecomposition.Norm2
member.summary: Gets the two norm.
member.value: The two norm; max(S).

member.name: P:Atom.Math.SingularValueDecomposition.Condition
member.summary: Gets the two-norm condition number.
member.value: The two-norm condition number; max(S)/min(S).

member.name: P:Atom.Math.SingularValueDecomposition.Rank
member.summary: Gets the effective numerical matrix rank.
member.value: The number of non-negligible singular values.

member.remarks: This operation clones internal data, be careful when calling this method.

member.summary: Gets the diagonal matrix of singular values.
member.remarks: This operation clones internal data, be careful when calling this method.
member.returns: A new Matrix that contains the singular values of the decomposed Matrix.

member.summary: Gets the left singular vectors (U matrix).

member.param: The X-coordinate of the point.
The Y-coordinate of the point.
The X-coordinate of the triangle's first vertex.
The Y-coordinate of the triangle's first vertex.
The X-coordinate of the triangle's second vertex.
The Y-coordinate of the triangle's second vertex.
The X-coordinate of the triangle's third vertex.
The Y-coordinate of the triangle's third vertex.
member.returns: Returns if the point resides in the triangle; or otherwise if the point is outside the triangle.

member.name: T:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions
member.summary: Static helper class that contains special math functions.
member.remarks: Those functions have been taken from the Math.NET Iridium library. Full credit goes to Christoph Regg and Contributors. See list on the top.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.GammaLN(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of Gamma for a real value > 0.
member.param: The input value.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the gamma function for real values (except at 0, -1, -2, ...). For numeric stability, consider to use GammaLn for positive values.
member.param: The input value.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.GammaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the regularized lower incomplete gamma function P(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) * int(exp(-t)t^(a-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, x > 0.
member.param: The first input value.
The second input value.
member.exception: If or is less than zero.
member.returns: The regularized lower incomplete gamma function.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.Digamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the digamma (psi) function of real values (except at 0, -1, -2, ...). Digamma is the logarithmic derivative of the function.
member.param: The input value.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.Beta(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the Euler Beta function of real valued z > 0, w > 0.
member.remarks: Beta(z,w) = Beta(w,z).
member.param: The first input value.
The second input value.
member.returns: The Euler Beta function of and .

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.BetaLN(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of the Euler Beta function of real valued z > 0, w > 0.
member.remarks: BetaLn(z,w) = BetaLn(w,z).
member.param: The first input value.
The second input value.
member.returns: The natural logarithm of the Euler Beta function of and .

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.BetaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the regularized lower incomplete beta function I_x(a,b) = 1/Beta(a,b) * int(t^(a-1)*(1-t)^(b-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, b > 0, 1 >= x >= 0.
member.param: The first positive input value.
The second positive input value.
The third input value; must be in |0..1|.
member.returns: The regularized lower incomplete beta function.
member.exception: If any of the parameters is out of valid range.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.Error(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the error function of .
member.remarks: erf(x) = 2/sqrt(pi) * int(exp(-t^2),t=0..x);
member.param: The input value.

member.name: M:Atom.Math.SpecialFunctions.ErrorInv(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse error function erf^-1(x).

remarks.p: The algorithm uses a minimax approximation by rational functions and the result has a relative error whose absolute value is less than 1.15e-9.
See the page for more details.

member.param: The input value.

member.summary: Error function contants.

member.summary: Error function contants.

member.summary: Error function contants.

member.summary: Error function contants.
